Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: The ratio of boys to girls in a family is 5:7. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Input:To locate a choker not located in a jewelry box or boutique where would you go? Choices:  A: jewelry store B: neck C: jewlery box D: jewelry box E: boutique<n><n>### Response:		Answer the requested question.<n>A: jewelry<n><n>### Instructions:Complete the requested task. You may use the following prompts as a guide if necessary.<n>A: a necklace<n>B: a ring, bracelet, or earrings<n>C: oral<n><n>### Input A:<n>I want to locate a specific piece of jewelry. You should be able to find it quickly. I'm sure it can be a stressful search, so I hope things run smoothly between you and the jeweler.<n><n>### Response A:<n>This will be an easy task.<n><n>### Input B:<n>I want to find the necklace I lost so long ago. It would be wonderful if you could find it.<n><n>### Requested to locate a necklace.<n><n>### What I'm saying:I’m looking for a specific piece of jungle<n><n>### Response B:<n>I can't make any guarantees, but I will do my best to find your lost necklace.<n><n><n>### Input C:<n>I need more than a simple locator with a magnifying glass to find the bracelet I misplaced somewhere in the pantry.<n><n>### How can I help you find the location of the bracelet?<n><n>### Request: I need a locator with a magnificing glass.<n><n>### Why this task is helpful<n><n>This may get me to find important things<n><n>### Instrumental Conditioning<n><n>Instrumental conditioning is the process where a person performs an act or completes a task. With this tactic, people learn by doing, which is what makes it particularly impactful. This type of conditioning also allows for higher-level decision making and thinking to evolve within a learner's brain. Through the completion of multiple repetitious tasks or assignments, students are able to process multiple pieces of information at once. In order to perform a task to its fullest potential, instructional designers must determine what task will best assist the learner in developing new skills and concepts.

How many hours does she spend shopping?<n>### Response : 24 hours<n><n>### Answer A: The only baggage that the woman checked was a trash bag.  Where was she heading?<n>### Answer: Military<n><n>### Response B: She rents out her carriage house at 50 dollars a day or 500 dollars for fourteen days.  Eric wants 20 days and asks how much? <n><n>### Response : $40 dollars<n><n>## <n><n>I have no Idea what your doing. <n><n>![Logo of a car, in the foreground and a house in the background](/static_files/docs/logos/car.png)<n><n>I have no idea what your doing.<n><n>You can see my code when you click on it and view the source. Choices:  A: write an essay B: organize thoughts C: speak information D: summarize main points E: have information<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>1. How many times each day do you do the following?<n>Choices:  A: I get up and wash my face in the morning<n>B: I take a bath in the evening after work<n>C: I shampoo my hair every other day<n>D: I brush my teeth twice a day<n>E: I change my clothes daily<n>2. There are 365 days in a year, so we eat 365 meals. If we can eat out 5 times a year, how many meals a year should we eat out?<n>Choices: A: 5 meals B: 10 meals C: 90 meals D: 150 meals E: 200 meals<n>3. If she saves $7,500 a year, how much money will she have when she’s 10 3 years from now?<n>Choices:<n><n>### Instantiation Guidelines:<n>When a student asks you a question, it is important to ask clarifying questions to gain a deeper understanding of their knowledge level and where to start. Here are some guidelines for interacting with the student.<n><n>1. Begin any interaction by listening to the student and focusing on what they said rather than what you feel you need to say.<n>2. Listen to learn where their thought and understanding processes are.<n>3. Avoid assuming or jumping to assumptions.<n>4. Guide the student by asking a clarifying question. This makes them take action to engage.<n>5. Guide the student by giving them information about the topic or assignment requirements.<n>

Write the article so that it would be useful to readers in any environment, at work, at home, or in the car.<n><n>### Details:<n>The article must be 400 words (approximately 6 paragraphs).<n><n>1. Select a topic of an interest to many readers of your magazine. This article is not about your personal interests.<n>2. Start with an interesting sentence or two.<n>3. Write your article in complete sentences.<n>4. Include details that support your ideas.<n>5. Make your writing clear, focused, and interesting.<n><n>### Answer:<n><details><summary><span style="color: red">Solution</span></summary><n><b><i>Choices:</i></b><n><span><b>A:</b></span><n>Choosing The Right Lightbulbs<n><p>Have you ever gone to the store to buy a new lightbulb to replace an old one only to return home realizing you bought the wrong kind?<n><p><n><p>This can be quite frustrating, however it can be easily avoided if you plan before you go to the store. When trying to pick a new lightbulb, it can be difficult to know what to look for, even with signs that try to help you<n><p><n><n><p>The most important thing to look for is the wattage and type, which are both written on the bulb. Wattage is measured in watts and is indicated by a number in front of the bulb.  If the number is higher than the number you need you could easily return the bulb and exchange it for one with a smaller wattage. Typically this number will either be at 60, 75, or 100.<n><p><n>The letter indicates the type of bulb it is.  Often times the bulbs are separated into four different types:<n><ol type=”1"><n><li><b>A:<br/></b>This is your Incandescent bulbs.  They are the standard, traditional bulbs that were around before modern lighting.  They get warm

In a particular floor level, the maximum distance from one side of<n>floor to another is 47 feet. If he walks at a speed of 7/5 foot/s and the distance he can cover at one stride is<n>20 feet, how many strides will be required by him to walk at fastest speed from one corner of that floor to other (assuming<n>that he moves in straight line.) Choice:  A. 5, B. 9, C.10, D. 8, E. 13<n><n>### ResponseA man is standing on the top of elevator. In a top most floor, he needs to walk at a speed of 5/4 foot/s to cover the<n>maximum distance from one corner from another side. So, if he takes 13 strides, he will reach at top at fastest speed.<n>  <n>### Input A boss wants to find out what would happen to the total revenue of the company, if sales increase 15% during the<n>holiday season. Choice A. B. C. D. E.<n><n>### Response Sales are expected to increase by 85%<n><n>### Input The volume of a cube is decreased by 50% and then again it is increased by 35%. Find its final volume when area of<n>cube has decreased to one third of initial volume.<n><n>### The answer is<n>   A.  93.14%<n>   B.  55.2%<n>   C.  84.17%<n>   D.  27.2%<n>   E.  54.44

Home D: hot room E. Office<n><n>Response: Answer the following question I am!<n><n>### Exposure:<n>Instructions: How much the girls get if the girls get $900 to divide among themselves?<n><n>Output: 760<n><n>### Solution :<n><n><n>Giving 900 dollars among 30 children (5 boys and 25 girls), so that the total number of girls who collect 560 dollars<n><n>Total number of children who collect 340<n><n>### Instances:<n>Instructions : "Who's first?" Answer "I am!"<n><n>Instructions:Who's second?<n><n>Answer:"You are."<n>Instructions:And you think?"<n><n>Answer: "I am also."

There are 480 - 40 in a day; there are 30 days in a month. So there are (480 - 30) x (60 - 40) = 12600 seconds in a month.<n><n>### Demo<n>Given :  61 seconds<n><n>### Output<n>16 seconds (2 months and 2 days)<n>

Choices:  C: joyful or D: Very important<n><n>### Explanation:<n><n>C) Change the learning process to be joyful<n><n>### Input<n>Journalist:How do you think your education had prepared you most in life?<n><n>Student Answering:<n><n>Education is not about getting an ideal job. It is about having the capacity to make intelligent decisions at any given point in time. A good degree, a diploma, or a master-degree does not guarantee your job security. This is why you should focus on gaining more skills and on having the competencies that employers are looking for.<n><n>### Solution<n><n>The degree program was really good; although a great deal of what was taught was never used in my professional life. The best education is when you learn by doing, learning by doing things that you like, something you want to do or something you want to be.<n>I started with a great job out of college. But I was ready and had the capability to do more. The job I got right after finishing my bachelor degree was a great starting point, and I had to learn everything I could to find new opportunities. I worked hard and was able to advance my career in a short period of time. I then decided to do an MBA, not because of a job but to learn something new, because I was looking for new challenges and I wanted to do different things. I did not see my degree as a job guarantee, but instead a stepping stone to a new career. I thought I could do more and be more. I wanted to start my own business instead of working for others. But I have seen people graduate with a bachelor degree and a masters degree and work for their company for the rest of their career. And that is also great.<n><n>### Question:How do you like taking classes at the moment? Does it remind you of being in Highschool? Why?

If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Input:Riding bike through rough terrain can be dangerous, one could find themselves what? Choices:  A: pleasure B: accident C: get somewhere D: hurt E: falling down<n><n>### Response:		Answer: accident<n><n>### Feedback: Choice A is incorrect because one can still find pleasure in riding a bike through difficult terrain. Choice B is incorrect because it is impossible to have accidents if one is not actually riding a bike. Choice C is incorrect because it would not be possible to ‘get somewhere’ or ‘hurt’ oneself when biking through rough terrain, as it is impossible to achieve such actions, and Choice D is incorrect as it is unreasonable to ‘hurt’ yourself or ‘fall down’ when biking through difficult terrain. Hence, the answer is ‘accident’ since it answers the question in the most correct manner.<n><n>### Input The population of Texas is estimated at 22 million. The population of Utah is estimated at 2.9 million. The population of California is estimated at 36 million. What is the total population of all three of these states?<n><n>### Response Answer: 16.8 million<n><n>### Feeback The population of Utah, Texas, and California is the total number of people in those states. To calculate that, multiply 22 by 2.9, then multiply it by 36 to get a total number of 82.7 million. However, 82.7 is much higher than 16.8(the population of all three states combined). The answer is 16.8.<n><n>### Answer the following multiple choice question<n><n>Question: A square has eight sides. What is the perimeter of the square?<n>Answers: 80<n><n>Question: How would one describe a parallelogram with only two parallel sides?<n>Answers:(Parallelogram) A quadrilateral having only two pairs of parallel sides<n><n>Question: The difference between the lengths of the two legs of an isosceles trapezoid which are 8 and 12. <n>Answers:(8 - 12) 4  <n><n>Question: A circle has a diameter of 10.  What is its radian measure?<n>Answers 2pi  <n><n>Question: How many diagonals does a rhombus have?<n>Answers Two<n><n><n>### Instructions:  This task was given to respondents as a verbal prompt. Choices:  A: driveway B: the event C: scrap heap D: parking garage E: repair shop<n><n>### Response:		B<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input: There are a total of n cars with fuel costs $C and $T that cost $10/gallon. How much fuel costs would result in the largest possible profit, where n is 7 and $C = 3.5, $T = 0.<n><n>In order to maximize profit, you will have to find the intersection of both equations. Subtracting all of the rows from the first equation from the second equation, one can arrive at the following inequality:<n><n>155 > 12n(7-n)t^(7-n)/7n<n>155 - 12n(5-n)/7n > 0<n>-12n/7n > -54, if n = 7, the intersection of both equations is<n>Fuel Cost = $T = -59/$10 = -5.9<n>Profit = <n>$(59 × 2)−7(59 × 2$/7$)) = $244.9<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Input and Response:<n><n>![image](readme.jpg)<n><n>* A [link](http://www.code.org/sandboxes/hz4c2d)<n>To make it easier to understand, use the buttons to go to a certain slide.<n>  Click on the black arrows in the corner to move left or right, or click on the red arrows and numbers to go to a certain time in the video.<n>Here are the slides:<n>1. Demonstration 1/2, If it takes her 5 hours to drive to town<n>9. Demonstration/response: How much money does  each boy receive.<n>10. Demonstration How much fuel costs would<n>11. You can thank our programmers for that! We know that gy mnasiu m is the correct answer for this question. We programmed gy mnasiu m into our question program. We also assigned a unique category ID to the gy mnasiu m category.  We assigned each question that we've added to the program an ID. We decided that gy mnasiu was its CATEGORY ID. We'll also define the question program for you. You can find the question program in your folder. It's called gy mnasiu.ml. We'll discuss this example below.<n><n>### Examples:<n>### 1. If the program defined below is executed, what will be the value of the variable car?<n><n>(defcar(<n><n>(addcats [a] "1)Fortune teller" "3)Restaurant" "5)Cemetery" "8)Dog food")<n><n>(defcar cat[x] (car [x]))<n><n>(defcar car [x] (car (getcat [x] "1)Four")))<n><n>(def car (<n><n>(getcat ((car x) 1) 2)))<n><n>### Answer:Dog food <n>##<n>## 3. Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: The ratio of boys to girls in a family is 5:7. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Input:What might someone do who is having fun? Choices:  A: being happy B: glee C: smoke D: stress relief E: may laugh<n><n>### Response:		What might someone do when they are sad? Choices: A: make a meal B: laugh C: mourn D: be depressed E: get rid of stress<n><n>### Input and Output Examples<n>Input:How many cows did the rancher drive to higher ground?<n><n>Answer: 440<n><n>Input : 2020<n>Answer: 20,000<n><n>### Demystify:What do you think you know about this instruction?<n><n>### Demote:what do you think you don't know about this instruction?

Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Input:They wanted to eat at home but the cupboards were barren, so they had to go what? Choices:  A: having appointements B: being late C: have time to think D: time consuming E: impatience<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>*   For each line of the program, copy the prompt, write, and correct the syntax error.<n><n>Copy the error and write the correct solution. Each input contains 1 line.<n><n>### Input<n>```<n>Program: If the variable num is greater than 0, write: “I’ve got good news!”; otherwise, write: “Bummer!”<n>```<n><n>**Correct Syntax**<n>```<n>Program: IF num > 0 THEN Write: “I’ve Got Good News!” ELSEIF Bummer!<n>```<n><n>### Response<n><n>### Instuctions:<n><n>If you are trying to use an input prompt and then a response prompt you have to make a IF-ELSEIF-ELSEIF-END prompt.<n><n>### Example: <n><n>**CORRECT IF-ELSEIF*<n><n>![Response][Response]<n>Program: Display the prompt: “Would you prefer to see this morning or this evening?’”<n>Choices:  Morning, evening, or both.<n><n>![Program][Program1]<n>Input<n>```<n>Program: Display the first prompt: Would you prefer to see this<n>morning or this evening?<n>```<n>**CORRECT RESPONSE**<br><n>```<n>Program:  If morning Choices: “morning”<br><n>ELSE IF evening: “evening”<br><n>Else: “Both”<br><n>End <n>```<n><n>## Tasks<n><n>- [ ] Create and execute an instruction<n>```<n>Input: Display the following prompt, followed by the prompt “1 OR 2?.”<n>   Input: “Which is the better way to go?,” followed by “1 OR 2?”<n><n>Output: “Take 1 or 2 as appropriate.”<n>```<n><n>[ ] Create and execute an IF-ELSEIF statement<n>```<n><n>**COPY AND CORRECT**<n><n>Program: Display “We’d gladly accept a personal cheque payable to ‘Apex Inc.’” while a personal cheque is being filled <n>out. IF the prompt is a cheque, write a statement explaining the need to have the cheque notarized.<n>```<n><n>**CORRECTION**<n>```<n>Program<n>```<n>### IN

Choices:  A: united states B: atlas C: developed land D: park E: countryside<n><n>### Response:		<n>B<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the following multiple-choice question.<n><n>## Instruction:Answer the question about the passage you've just read.<n><n>## Demonstration:The most common species of turtle in the world is the common (or eastern) box turtle. This species is indigenous to Eastern North America, but it is found all over the USA and into Latin America. The box turtle is unique among the world's roughly 300 turtle species in that its shell protects them from danger with a hinged lid. It's like a car that you can close to protect you. It's interesting that the only part of the box turtle shell that grows is the lid. Some other species of turtles actually grow their shells bigger and bigger as they age! The box turtle spends most of its life buried in the ground. Its camouflage allows it to hide from threats such as hawks and snakes who see them, but don't immediately think they are food. This protective strategy works well except when a box turtle is exposed to danger. Turtles have amazing eyesight, and a box turtle's eyes allow it to spot a potential predator from a great distance. Predators must then make a speedy approach. At night box turtles will also retreat to the ground to stay safe.<n><n>**Instruction:Which type of turtle is described in this passage?**<n><n>A boxed caravan<n><n>A boxed dirt mover<n><n>B: the eastern box turtle<n><n>D: the western box turtle<n>

How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: The ratio of boys to girls in a family is 5:7. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Input:Where is a good place to buy moistener? Choices:  A: bathroom B: purse C: drug store D: hand lotion E: water<n><n>### Response:		C<n>

Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: The ratio of boys to girls in a family is 5:7. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Input:Danny was having fun singing in front of his class.   He has a lot of what? Choices:  A: laughter B: being happy C: glee D: opera E: injuries<n><n>### Response:		C  <n>Explanation: Danny was having fun singing, that means he was 'greet'. The word is laughter, not greet, and therefore D is the correct answer <n><n>### Input :   The cost of renting a bike is $4 an hour. On the first day of the rental, the cost for renting a bike to John is $14. On the second day of the rental to John, the cost is $16. For one day of rental, the cost is $8. How many days did John rented the bike? Please provide your thoughts and the math you used.<n><n>### Response : C  <n>Explanation : John rented the bikey for one day, the bike cost of $8, which means John rented for just 1(one) day, and therefore 1(one) is the correct answer!!<n><n>### Input 1:   A store advertises a 30% discount on any purchase over $50. If a customer buys 10 items that cost $50 each, how much does he save?<n>### Response 1: B <n>Explanation 1:  The customer buys 1, which means the 30% discounce applies to the last number, meaning that discount of 30% is applied on $50. Therefore $15 is the correct answer

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: The ratio of boys to girls in a family is 5:7. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Input:What do humans take in while breathing? Choices:  A: lungs and diaphram B: oxygen C: abdominal muscles D: air E: open throat<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>### Answer:<n>[C](http://www.answergarden.com/answer/619911863138832)<n>![](https://github.com/PabloHernandez/HW-10/raw/main/Screen%20Shot%202022-01-12%20at%2011.13.31%20PM.png)<n><n>### My Solution:<n><n>When the task asks to "input information", it means the system that is asking for that information may only use that information to form the next action (output of an AI).  The system that is asking for this data doesn't know what is beyond those answers, in which we as humans have knowledge about the world.<n><n>For this task, my approach was to eliminate the possible incorrect answers, then pick the most likely one.  This is why "D" was incorrect because an open throat and an abdominal muscles would have a significant impact on a person's physical appearance.<n><n>![](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o7WZUQhGtOwCjrq08/giphy.gif)<n><n>If the other choices are incorrect, the remaining choices are probably the highest and lowest.<n><n>![](http://www.dailygood.org/media/kubrick_shallow.jpg)<n><n><n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: The ratio of boys to girls in a family is 5:7. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Input:John is getting something important.  What does this make him feel? Choices:  A: then have B: headaches C: stoic D: being happy E: wanting more<n><n>### Response:		<n>If the answer is A: than the correct answer is <n><n>### Input Choices: <n>A: then have B: stoic C: being headaches D: want more and E: happy<n><n>### Response Choices:<n>The correct answer <n><n>John is getting something important<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write a program that:<n><n><n>- Requires the user to enter one or more choices, e.g., "Choices:  A: headaches B: something important C: being headaches".<n>- Accepts each choice, e.g. "then have".<n>- Writes the requested information. E.g. if the user chooses "A: then have", the program should say "John is getting something important".<n><n><n>### Notes:<n>The program must allow a user to enter more than one choice. For example, if the user enters "A: then have B", the program should say _John is getting something important_.<n><n>You will want a structure with multiple decision statements.<n><n><n><n><n>Example:  How to print numbers from 1 to 31<n><n>1) Choice:  Input: A=1, B=13, C=23, Input: A=0, B=3, C=3<n><n>2) Case: A=1<n><n>      Then output 1<n><n> 3) Case: B=13<n><n>     Output 13 and go back to case for A<n><n> 4) Case: C=23<n><n>       Output 23<n><n>13) Output 31 and go back to case<n><n>

If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: The ratio of boys to girls in a family is 5:7. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Input:I'm watching tv because there is nothing else to do, what do I expect to get from this? Instruction: Answer the following multiple-choice question.](https://regex101.com/r/cI5lR0/1)<n><n>### Instructions Answer the following multiple- choice question.<n><n>> In a recent survey on the use of social media 10 out of 30 respondents said that they use Facebook daily. If the survey was conducted one month ago, how many of the respondents were using Facebook daily?<n><n>### Instruct:<n><n>The number of people who answered “yes” to the question, "Do you use social media daily?" divided by 10.<n><n>If a survey was conducted one month in the past, there were 10 respondents who answered "yes" to the question, "do you use social media daily?"; if a survey was conducted two months into the past, there would be 20 respondents;<n><n>The result is as follows: <n><n>| Day | Person | Day1 | Day2 |<n>---|----|---|---|<n>| 1 | | | |<n>| 2 | 10 | 7 | 4 | <n>| 3 | | | | <n>| 4 | 5 | | | <n><n>### Result:<n>This number is 10 /1, 10/10, 10/11,... 5/1, 5/10, 5/11<n><n>The 100th day was not included, <n><n>### 100 = (30 * 10) = 300.<n><n>### 300 / (10 * 20) = 15<n><n><n># [6. Instruction: Answer one of the following questions.](https://regex1.com/r/_VW0O6)<n><n>### Draft: <n>1. If you divide a 180 square yard field for a football game into 10 squares that are each 18 square yard, how many yards is each square?<n><n>### Solution:<n><n>180 ÷ 10 = 18<n><n>### Solution

The demand for t-shirts is increasing. As a result, every t-shirt you own costs way more than it did before. We can conclude that<n><n>Input:  T-shirt producers should not increase supply if the price is less than the average cost. The demand for t shirts will decrease as a result.<n><n>### Response 1: The price of t-shirt has gone way up at market over the last month so demand will increase.  As a result of this increasing demand, price will increase. The increase in price means that the average cost will increase  so the producers should increase supply and not decrease it. The answer consists of only one choice.</p><n><n>## Task:<n><n>## Instructions:<n><n>## Demonstration<n><n>## Input:Which of these is not a method a programmer uses to design a computer program? Choices:  a: create a prototype  b: implement a data model  c: design graphics  d: evaluate the program<n><n>## Response:B<n><n>In Python this is what you should have.<n>`def add_numbers(x,y): return x+y`<n>`def sub_numbers(x, y): return x -y`<n><n>### Task 2.<n><n>## Instruations: <n><n>## Demonstation:<n><n>## Input: How can a data type be thought of as a class? Choices:  b: the class and data type can have the same properties  c: the class is a data type  d: the class can contain data  e: the class is the data type<n><n>## Response: A<n><p>Data types and classes share the same attributes. These are also called properties.</p><n><n><n>## Instrucions:How can someone make a class more complex? Choices:  d: add members to the class  c: add variables to the class  b: define a new class  a: call another class  e: create a new class member<n><n>## Response:a<n><n><p>A class can inherit attributes from other classes.</p><n><n><p>It can also be used as a base class. This is where you learn from a class you already have and create a new class out of it, usually making it more complicated.</p><n>

If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Input:Where do fish spend the majority of their time? Choices:  A: body of water B: lake superior C: underwater D: toilet E: aquarium<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>A:  Body of water<n>    <n>```<n><n>```<n><n>### Input<n>```<n>The cat slept with the dog.<n>```<n><n>## Problem:<n><n>### Given this code, answer the following questions.<n>1. Whenever you go shopping for food/dinner, what does your mom typically make?<n>   * Be specific. Give a detailed example of what kind of food your mother gets.<n>2. A friend that is new to my area asked me what my favorite restaurant is and what foods to order. I recommended my favorite restaurant and also the specific dishes/foods to order.<n><n>### Given the following code, make sure to explain what each code line<n>is doing, then comment on the code below the code so that<n>the reviewer can tell what you were thinking about as you wrote the code.<n><n>```<n>var dogPersonality = 'a dog; a dog of many attributes’<n>for (i = 0; i <= dogPersonality.length; i++)<n>{<n>    var name = dogPersonality[i].toUpperCase();<n>    if (name === ‘A’) { console.log(3); }<n>    else { console.log(2);  }<n>}<n>```<n><n>## Question:<n><n>### Give yourself points for the following<n>### When writing code, what should you do when there is an error?<n>  * Add an if else statement _____ <n>  <n>  * Add comments to indicate what you are thinking ______<n>  * Always write a line of code to print error messages ________<n>  * Add an else part to catch an error when something does not work as planned _______

Choices:  A: make friends B: mingle C: meet people D: small talk E: meet new people<n><n>### Response:		If you socialize by having useless conversations it is called small talk. Small talk is a type of social interaction that is brief, casual, and not meant to be serious or deep. It is often used in informal settings, such as when meeting new people or engaging in casual conversation. Small talk involves exchanging general information about topics such as the weather, current events, or personal interests. It is often used as an icebreaker to make a good first impression or to establish common ground with someone.<n><n>### Explanation: Small talk is a typeof social interaction that is brief casual, and not intended to be serious or deep, such as when meeting someone.<n>

Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: The ratio of boys to girls in a family is 5:7. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Input:If you hit someone while driving what could happen to that person? Choices:  A: deaths B: get arrested C: moving D: using gas E: may die<n><n>### Response:		The correct answer would be if you hit someone while driving you could do any any of the above answers

He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Input:James went to the best steakhouse outside of the South.  Where is James? Choices:  A: dairy farm B: texas C: building D: michigan E: florida<n><n>### Response:		James is in Texas<n>1. The South includes all states on the American southern side of the 100th parallel and excludes all states in the east. The United states has two main parts the Southern part includes all states in the South it does not include all states on the American south side of the 1-0/100 parallel. 2.James the best steakhouse in the south is called Texas Steakhouse it's located in Austin Texas. If you take the 501 from Dallas, TX the route takes two hours and 15 minutes.<n><n>### Input,James went to see the famous Dallas Cowboys play their home game at AT&T Stadium. B: houston Texans C: Detroit Lions D: San Diego Chargers E: New York Giants.<n><n>### Response, San Diego Chargers<n><n>1. The Dallas Cowboys play the San Diego Chargers.

Choices:  A: backpack B: closet C: drawer D: dinner E: cupboard<n><n>### Response:		<n><n><n>#### Answer: a, c, e<n><n>### Explanation: The answer is a, c, e.  A utensil is used during dinner and that is what closet E is talking about.  But a utensil can be used for any of the evening activities, not just dinner.<n><n>### Output: <n><n>#### Dinner<n><n>#### Backpack<n><n>#### Drawer<n><n>#### Closet<n><n>#### Cabinet<n><n><n>### Output Explanation:<n>To store the clothes away and to put food into the fridge. It means I can do dinner or backpack to use utensils.  It also can be used for nightstand.  But the correct answer is dinner.<n><n>## Contributors<n><n>Micah Dixon, Lindsay Shanks and Natalee Winsten<n><n>## License<n><n>[![Creative Commons][cc-badge]][cc-url]<n><n>[cc-badge]: http://i.creativecommons.org/l/by/4.0/88x31.png<n>[cc-url]: http://creativecommons.org<n><n>

Choices:  A: turn away B: let down C: have to sleep D: run E: row boat<n><n>### Response:		<n>If there was no power then the boat would have to sleep which is human powered<n><n>### Input<n>What should be done to the car if there are more passengers then the front seat?<n>A.  Let the second person in the back seat<n>B.  Open the door<n>C.  Drive safely<n>D.  Have some fun<n><n>### Response<n>Have some fun<n><n>## Coded Task:<n>1.  Write a loop that goes from 1 to 5, and for each item in the list, multiply the item by 4.  <n>2.  Write a for loop that displays even numbers from 1 to 10.  <n>    3.  Write a function that adds two numbers.  <n>    4.  Write a for statement that prints the numbers 1 to 13 inclusive.  <n>    5.  Write a function to find which month has the fewest days. (December has 12 days, January has 31 days, etc.)  <n>        Write a for loop that prints the names of the months.<n>        <n>    6.  Write a for expression that produces numbers from 1 to your age.<n>        1.  Write a for statment that creates a new car (color, year, make, model, etc.) each time you cycle<n><n>### Instructions:Choose an element to use as a variable.  Then, for each item within the for loop make the following expression:<n><n>Input: for a in range(3,10):    <n>            print(a, a ** 2)<n>Output: 3 12, 6 36, 9 81        <n><n><n><n>### Comments<n><n>### Tests:<n><n>### Output:<n><n>### Resources:<n><n>### Instructor Feedback:<n>

Choices should be in lower case: “a”, “b”, “c”, “d”, or “e”.<n><n>### Instructions:Answer the question in the first input line.<n><n>### Incorrect<n><n>```javascript<n>let x,y,z;<n>console.log(eval(parse(z)));<n>```<n><n>### Correct<n><n>```javascript<n>var x,y,z=122;<n>console.log(""+(y*((z+"b")/y)));<n>```<n>

Choices:  A: waterfalls B: underwater C: beach D: surface of earth E: river<n><n>### Response:		The underwater part of the ocean is covered with water.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input: What’s half of half way?<n><n>### Demostration: HALF is half of the way. If you take the HALF of the way, then you will get halfway back from where you need to go. So the ANSWER is HALF of HALF way or even half way.<n><n>### Response<n>When there is a half in front of whatever, that means that you must take the half of the thing and make that your answer. It's a little weird, and sometimes there's a lot with half in front, but that doesn't really have much to do with it, you can just do it. Like, a half dozen of something is six. A half of a dozen is still six. So you take half and you get half, half way.<n><n>Example: <n>It's not 311/2 but it's half of 1/2.<n>To get your half you just have to use the word half. This can be tricky for kids even if they know that there's part of something, just do it. It's pretty simple and not really hard. This means that if you're half way, you have to go half way back and if it's a half of a day, you take half of the day and end up having the exact same day you started with.<n><n>Eg: There are half a dozen people in this room.

Hence, the correct choice is building.<n><n><n>### Inputs:<n>Input: The ratio x of boys to girls in the class (x = 4.4) is greater than 1.  The total number of students in the class is 86.  If a prize is awarded to the class with the greatest ratio of girls to boys, which class wins?<n><n>### Demostrations:<n>Choice A:  The first ratio that is greater than 1 and that includes a number other than 2 is 2.7. 86/2.7 = 32.<n>Choice B:  The number one less than the greatest integer such that that number divided by 2.7 equals 2 is 29. 86/ (29/2.7) = 7 5.28<n>Choice C:  The number in the interval that is less than 3 and greater than 2.5 is 2.75. 86/ 2.75 =  31<n>Choice D:  The number in interval that is less than the sum of 2 and 2/3 is 1.116. (86/1.116) =  77.696<n>Choice E:  The number between 1 and 1.5 is 1.25. 86/(1.25/2.7) 72 <n>Hence, the correct choice is choice A.<n><n><n>## Conclusion:<n>The correct choice was option A. Hence, the answer to this task is (b) the number of questions you will answer is the sum of the inputs that you have added. The choice that was incorrect was (d) the number of boys and girls = 180, the number of chairs facing the front  = 180 and the number of pears =0 because if you subtract the number of chairs and the number of pear  that will not give the sum of the number of students. So the choice that is incorrect is number of pears.<n><n>## Outputs for this task:<n><n>### Input : The ratio x of boys: to girls in a class (x

Choices:  A: two feet B: two ears C: horns D: lay eggs E: one head<n><n>### Response:		<n>Write a method named "guess" that contains statements to solve the task. Include comments to indicate the name of the method, the types of the parameters supplied to it, and the purpose of the method. Call the method from the user defined main method, and include a statement that prints the answer to the question.<n><n>## Solution<n>```java<n>static int Guess(String question,int n){<n><n>  int ans = (int) (Math.random() * n + 1);<n> return ans;<n>};<n><n>public static void main(String[] args) {<n><n>  Scanner scan = new Scanner(System.in);<n>    int n = scan.nextInt()-1;<n>    //printing the nth element in the sequence..<n><n>    int guess = Guess(question,n);<n><n> System.out.println("Answer:"+guess);<n>}<n>```<n>

If not, move to section A for more instruction on how to complete the task correctly.<n><n>### Student response:In a small town, two people get married each week. On Monday, the bride is 18 years old and a week later the groom is 25 years old. How old are they 8 weeks later when the next person marries?<n><n>### Student correction<n>They will be 30 years older.<n><n>### Comments:<n> <n>### Demonstion<n>1. The two people get married at different days of the week (Monday and Tuesday).<n>2. Each week, the age of the two people are incremented by the days the weddings occur<n> <n>### Answer<n>Answer 1<n>It may be helpful to draw a calendar as a visual aid while working on this task.<n><n>If the person 1 and the person 8 are getting married at 1pm, then two weeks later one will be 19 and the other 26.  To add on a number of days to that, multiply the number of days by the initial number.<n><n>### Notes:<n>  1. You don't need to write down anything.<n>  2. If the math is not needed, don’t do it.<n><n>### Questions:<n>1. How will you explain this to a parent?<n><n>2. Why did you decide to use the calendar?<n><n>3. Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: The ratio of boys to girls in a family is 5:7. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Input:Who designs a building? Choices:  A: builders B: driver C: architect D: fall down E: tradesmen<n><n>### Response:		The architect is responsible for how a building looks, is designed the way you describe it, and is also responsible for how much it costs to build.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Which of these things is not a type of machine made by humans? Choices: A: trampoline B: steam engine C: trolling motor D: bunny eared radio antenna<n><n>### Response<n><n>B is not a type of a machine made by humans.<n><n>### Riddle<n><n>I weigh the same when I'm empty as when I'm full, what am I?<n><n>### Answer:<n><n>### Instructions:<n><n>Rewrite this code as you understand it so that the output will be "300".<n>1. if(number >= 150 && number <= 567)<n>2. {<n>//your code here<n>}<n>3. else<n>4. {<n>//your output here<n>}<n><n>### Demostration Instructions:<n>1. if(Number >= 150 )<n>2. {<n>    number = 292<n>3. }<n>4. }<n>if(Number >= 200 && Number <= 350)<n>5. {<n>    number=250<n>6. }<n>7. }</br><n><n>### Comments Instructions:<n>A comment's purpose is to provide instructions, information, or data for people who may access the code later. Comments are sometimes also used to record an explanation of the code or a memory.<n>All comments can be included on one line in all C/C++/Java languages, but the syntax for each of the three differs slightly.<n><n>Notes Instructions:<n>These can be placed anywhere in the program code, unlike comments, which can only be placed in the start/end of a line or at the top of a page but not in the middle of a line<n><n>### Code Comment Instructions:<n>All comments in C++ or C must begin with a '//' (double slash) and can continue until that character is closed.<n>JAVA code comments can be made in the beginning of the coding sequence (//)and in the C++, they can be placed in the middle while in C, it must be on the start.<n>```<n>//This is a comment<n>//

Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Input:A person who wants to make more at their job but can't will often need to find a what? Choices:  A: own house B: better job C: win lottery D: save money E: feel safe<n><n>### Response:		<n>E<n><n>---<n>### Instruction<n>The number of bikes, B, that can be stored in your garage is equal to 5 x B.  What's the number of bikes you can store in your garage?<n><n>This is a binary expression in which a variable is used.  In this case, B is the variable.  The number 5 is repeated as the constant, also known as a base, which is the number 5.  <n><n>### Demostration:<n>In this scenario, you are storing bikes in your garage, not houses.  A garage doesn't have to be the size of a home or even bigger than a home to hold as many bikes as bikes are listed in your garage.  The number of bikes you have in your garage is five times bigger than when you have 0.  Bikes are in your garage when you have at least one bike in your garage.<n><n>### Analysis:<n>An expression tells you the answer to a problem.  A base is used with a number for the answer, in this case, the number 5.  As a general rule, the number 5 is used as a base, but it does not have to be 5.  It can be any number.<n><n>---<n>## Instruction:Answer the question below with a complete sentence.<n><n>In addition to the expression on the card, what else is included inside each box?<n>

His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Input:The forgotten leftovers had gotten quite old, he found it covered in mold in the back of his what? Choices:  A: carpet B: refrigerator C: breadbox D: fridge E: coach<n><n>### Response:		A: carpet<n><n>### Rationale:  The word that should be placed in the blank is "fridge", because the leftovers are old, covered in mold in a refrigerator; the word "coach" does not refer to a refrigerator. (It is an idiom referring to a person.) The word "back" refers to the back of the fridge.<n><n>### Note: The correct answer is A: carpet.<n><n>### Input :This store is not only known for its large variety of grocery store items but also its inexpensive prices, but the store’s what’s? Choices:  store’s A: products B: grocery C: items D: meats E: groceries<n><n>### Response :A: grocery store items<n><n>### Rational:  The blank is an adjective describing grocery items; the word "meats" does not refer to grocery items.<n><n>### input:This clothing store is known for its inexpensive prices but the store’s  what’s Choices:  store's A: selection B: selections C: selection D: price E: products<n><n>### Response  :B: selections<n><n>### Ration:  The blank is a plural noun; a singular noun would be incorrect.(selections vs. a selection)<n><n>### Input  :This clothing store is now offering 50% off their  what’s? Choises:  store's products A: selection B: new arrivals C: selection of D: selection E: products<n><n><n>### Response   :The correct answer is Choose C: selection of.<n><n>### Rantional:  The blank is plural and refers to several types of clothing items from a store.<n><n>### The correct answer is Choose A: selection.<n><n>### This clothing Store is now offering 25% off its  what in January? Choices:A: new arrivals B: selection of C: selection D: products E: selection<n><n>### Response A: selection<n><n>## What is the price of five pounds of chicken?<n>## Input: A 5-pound chicken costs $5.00. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: The ratio of boys to girls in a family is 5:7. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Input:Bill is stuck in marsh when a man comes up to him peaking Cajun, where is he? Choices:  A: low lands B: new york C: forest D: louisiana E: everglades<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>Answer: B: new york<n>```<n><n>### Instructions: <n>You are to write 15 responses in total<n><n>### Instrument:  <n>Cognitive Walk-Through: A  tool that assesses a solution by focusing on the understanding  of input (what the problem is and the instructions) and by the analysis of the  response (the solution).  <n>It is useful  in exploring the  cognitive processes underlying a solution.  It may be used as a tool  for evaluation and/or instructional planning to determine if there are any  conceptual or skill gaps.<n><n>### Guidelines: <n>Cognitive Walk through consists of both a set of guidelines and a scoring rubric. The  guidelines are divided into two focuses: <n>What the Input Says (WIS) and What the  Response Says (WRS). The scoring rubric includes the following five  categories and levels:<n><n>* Category:  Instructions<n>* Description:  <n>* Criteria: A response that appropriately complements the request.<n>* Level 1:  Acceptable<n>* Level 2:   Exemplary<n>  <n>[1]: https://github.com/turan-sabiret/E-Learning-Teaching-Interactive-Tutor-Tools/blob/6723ed710c4cc2221e5e626cbbd14399738c51c4/Teaching%20Interactive%20tutor%20Tools/Teaching%5EEducational%20Robotics/Instructions_Educational%26Technological%20Robot.md "Educational & Technological Robot"
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: The ratio of boys to girls in a family is 5:7. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Input:When eating everything on the tasting menu, what does one tend to feel? Choices:  A: full stomach B: getting full C: gaining weight D: sick E: satisfaction<n><n>### Response:		C<n><n>### Instructions:<n>Write Python code that solves the problem. <n><n>### Input<n>A: full stomach<n><n>### Output<n>C: gaining weight<n><n>### How to run the code<n><n>```bash<n> python answer6.py<n>```<n><n>---<n>copyright (c) 2017 成吏萃言 公众号 @成吏评生

Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: The ratio of boys to girls in a family is 5:7. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Input:Sitting to close while watching TV can cause what sort of pain? Choices:  A: brain problems B: laziness C: get fat D: headache E: laughter<n><n>### Response:		Answer B.<n><n>### Input<n>```shell<n>	Sitting to close while<n>watching TV can cause<n>what sort of pain?<n>Choices: <n>A: brain problems<n>B: laziness<n>C: get fat<n>D: headache<n>E: laughter<n>```<n>### Response<n>```python<n>	def task1():<n>		answer = input("Choose your option A-> B-> C-> D->E  ")<n>	if answer == "A":<n>		return " Brain problems "<n>input("Please enter your answer after typing it. ")<n><n>	if answer ==  "B":<n>		return  "Laziness "<n>input("Please  enter your answer after typing  it  ")<n><n>	if  answer == "C":<n>		return 'Get fat '<n> input("Please enter your answer " + str(answer + " after typing  it ")<n><n>	if   answer  == "D":<n>		return (' Head ache'+ str(answer))<n> input("Please enter  your answer  after  typing  it ")<n>	if  answer  == "E":<n>		return (" Laughter ")<n> input("Please enter answer " + answer + " after typing  ")<n><n>if answer not in answerDict:<n>	return "please  enter your answer " + " from" + str(answer)<n> ```<n>### Result<n>``` shell<n> Brain problem<n>Laziness <n>Get fat<n>Head ache<n>Laughter <n>```

Choices:  A: tiredness B: living longer C: stomach ache D: illness E: acid reflux<n><n>### Response:		<n>The answer here is to D: illness. Tiredness and stomach ache are secondary signs of too much eating. If they are too much, the person will live a shorter life and get stomach ache and tiredness.<n><n>### Input<n>A woman is eating dinner at a restaurant at 6:30 and a woman in the next booth orders dinner at 7:10. A<n><n><n>### Instructions:Write a program that answers the following multiple choice question using your program.<n><n>### Input<n>The car-rental agencr has a promotion, which means that for a week, they will rent out<n>their cars for 3 days for only $17.  When someone enters the rental agency, the<n>receptionist asks the customer, “How many days will you renten the car?”<n><n>The receptionist then proceeds to write down each day of the rental period for each customer<n>and the price for each day.  Once the rental period has passed three days, the receptionist<n>should remove the cost of the last day from the total cost.<n><n>### Output<n><n><n>### Answer:<n><n><n>### The Question<n><n>How much does it cost to rent the car for 3 days?<n><n>### The Prompt<n><n>While at the car rental company, your car rental experience goes smoothly, and you are<n>asked ‘What day do you want the car?’ When each day is mentioned, the receptionist<n>writes a value on a list. This list begins the following:<n><n>\[<n>[Car:3days] \lvert [Monday:7] \lvert [Tuesday:7] \lVert [Wednesday:4] \lVert<n>\]<n><n>When the rental period is over, you give the car back, and the receptionist removes the<n>final day’s cost, and the three day rental price should be calculated by the following<n>equations:<n><n>\[Cost = \sum_{i=1}^{number of days=3}Price\]<n><n>For example, Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday.<n><n>Input:<n><n>Input:<n>[Car:3 days]<n>[Monday:5]<n>[Tuesday:3]<n>[Wednesday:2]<n>Output:<n>$30<n><n>Input:<n>Input[car:3days]<n>[Mondday:5]<n>[Wedessday:2]<n><n>Output:<n>$19<n><n>### Instructor Guide:<n><n><n>## Solution<n><n>### Demos:<n><n>#### Demo Input:1<n><n>Input: <n>[Car:3

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out. He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: The ratio of boys to girls in a family is 5:7. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Input:Though it stayed strictly indoors, the small dog felt like it had all the space in the world in the what? Choices:  A: living room B: dog park C: basket D: small apartment E: big house<n><n>### Response:		<n><n>> _I think it was really nice that you were staying strictly indoors because of the snow storm. At least you couldn't tell that you had to stay in your small apartment._<n>

Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: The ratio of boys to girls in a family is 5:7. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Input:Sam went to Paris where he ordered a blowfish at a sushi place.  Where was Sam? Choices:  A: books B: france C: fish market D: atlantic ocean E: cuba<n><n>### Response:		<n>```<n>In order to find this out I first needed to identify Sam’s location. In our example, Sam has told us in the first line of the paragraph that he went to Paris. The location information tells us that Paris is in Europe, which in turn is located in Europe somewhere off the coast of Spain.<n>```<n>```<n>The second line of the paragraph tells us that Sam was in Paris in a sushi place where he ordered a blow fish. After searching for this information, we find out that the sushi place is located beside the Seine River in Paris.<n>```<n>```{<n>  "location" :"sushi place",<n>  "nearby landmarks" : "Seine River in Paris",<n>  "nearest major city" : "Berlin"<n>}<n>```<n><n>```<n>The landmarks in the sushi place let us know that it is located on the east riverbank of the Seine River in Paris with the West Bank of the river on the other side of the city. We know this because the river divides the city into two parts.<n>```<n>```In the final landmarks we learned that Paris is the capital city of France and a major city in Europe. The city is known as “The City of Lights.” It’s also nicknamed the “Most Romantic City in the World.” Paris is the largest French city and also is located in France. The city was built on the Seine River in 52 BC. In 1871, Paris was besieged by the Prussians while a workers’ uprising occurred. The siege lasted for four months and the uprising lasted several days. In 1914, World War I began when Germany broke the neutrality treaty by launching an unprovoked attack against France. In 1851, the City of Paris was founded by Henry IV. The current President of France is Emmanuel Macron.<n>```<n>### Your Response<n>```<n>The first line tells us that he went to Paris where he probably was at the Eiffel Tower and the Seine River. Paris is located beside the Seine. The sushi place is where we would buy the blowfish for a delicious meal.<n>```<n>```The first line of the description is Paris,France. The second line says that he was at the sushi place in the river beside the Seine.

It costs you a total of $30 if you rent a car for seven days, and it costs you $230 if you rent it for seven hours or longer. How much would you spend if you rent the car for eight hours?<n><n>Example solution:<n>If we double the number we would get 45<n><n>### Step3<n>Use the expression above in the following statement:<n><n>###Step 3 response:Example question:How does it work?<n><n>It will charge you $45 because you rented the car for 8 hours.<n><n>The car rental might also charge you $10 because it takes extra time to pick up a car after it goes through a wagon. If you would rent a car for 10 hours, it would be $80.<n>

One was taken on a Monday and the picture the brother took was a Thursday.  The colors were completely different.  He was wearing a different color shirt and also had shorts on.  She was wearing a long sleeve shirt, and the background from her side of the house looked different.  Her side of the house was mostly bare and the pictures weren’t taken at the same time.  How is this similar to the original photograph?<n>Answer:  These were taken at different times and by different photographers.<n><n>### How to use:<n>-The pictures could've contained the same objects, but the people,  the shadows, or the angle might change.<n><n>### A<n>**The people, houses, cars and trees were the same** <n><n>### B<n>**Car and house are different**<n><n>### C<n>**The people are the same**<n><n>### D<n>**The house and people are different  **<n><n>### E<n>

The owner will then open the bag and allow the amount of bills in the bag to dictate the dollar entry-fees, which will be used to purchase cakes. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: The ratio of boys to girls in a family is 5:7. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Input:Bob and Boris were standing in a queue at the grocery store.  They were standing in place.  The line was fast, but the children in front of them were loud.   They were what? Choices:  A: frustration B: being annoyed C: delays D: irritation E: out of order<n><n>### Response:		<n>Answer with B. <n><n>### Input :  The groceries weighed 8 pounds.  How much did the order weigh in total?<n>Response: Answer with 8 pounds. <n><n>## Input:  Choose the closest value for the number of chocolate bars in a bag weighing 0.00 kg. Choices: A: 0 B: 2.5 C: 5.0 D: 7.5 E: 10,000,000.0<n><n>Response: Choose answer with E. <n><n>## Response:  Answer:<n>--- Choice A <n><n>The solution above was a response to question from the SOLVE: Basic Arithmetic Workbook

His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out. Choices:  A: big house B: nursery school C: preschool D: building E: retirement home<n><n>### Response:		<n>- Select "building": The spoiled child's "playroom" might be a spare room in the house.<n>- Select "big house": The playroom might be the entire house.<n><n>### Question<n>A pane of glass is 7/8 of a foot long, and the glass in the bottom panel of an antique door is broken, so the door cannot stay in the house. In order for the door to remain inside, the door must have another panel installed, because you will lose the bottom of the door if you take it away. How long, in inches, is the top panel of the door?<n><n>### Answer<n><n>Since the bottom panel of an door is broken, the door will be shorter when the top panel of the replaced it:<n><n>$7/8 - 1/8$<n>$6 7/8"$<n><n>$6 1/2"$<n><n>### Instructions:Use the multiple choice to answer the following question.<n><n>## Solution<n>
Below is an instruction that describes a task. Write a response that appropriately completes the request.<n><n>### Instruction:Answer the following multiple choice question.<n><n>### Demonstration:<n>Input: The car-rental agency charges $30/day for a car, or $190 for the first week for a rental that lasts an entire week or longer. Jennie rented a car for 11 days. How much, in dollars, did she pay for the rental?<n>Answer: 310<n><n>Input: A hurricane is approaching the southern coast of Texas, and a rancher is planning to move 400 head of cattle 60 miles to higher ground to protect them from possible inland flooding that might occur.  His animal transport truck holds 20 head of cattle.  Traveling at 60 miles per hour, what is the total driving time, in hours, it will take to transport all of his cattle to higher ground?<n>Answer: 40<n><n>Input: Jason has a carriage house that he rents out.  He’s charging $50.00 per day or $500.00 for 14 days.  Eric wants to rent the house for 20 days.  How much will it cost him?<n>Answer: 800<n><n>Input: Melissa works on a poultry farm. She drives to town twice each month to buy supplies. If it takes her 3 hours to drive to town and back, how many hours does Melissa spend driving in a year?<n>Answer: 72<n><n>Input: The ratio of boys to girls in a family is 5:7. The total number of children in the family is 180. If the boys are given $3900 to share, how much money does each boy receive?<n>Answer: 52<n><n>### Input:The parents thought their children should learn teamwork, what were they signed up for? Choices:  A: throw things B: play sports C: play games D: play ball E: play chess<n><n>### Response:		 D (Because ball has an -S and both ball and chess need teams to play them, this is the most correct response.)<n><n>### Input-How much does one inch of mercury equal to a difference on the temperature scale? Choices: A: 2° B: 0.5° C: 1° D: 7.5° E: 15°<n><n>### Response-C (1°)<n><n>### Input <n>In order to determine the weight of a house, someone can measure its volume and multiply that by a density factor. What must the density factor be equal to and what are its units?<n>Choices:<n>A. 38.22 pounds per cubic foot.<n>B. 55 pounds per cubic foot<n>C. 4850 pounds per cubic foot D 0.0004850 pounds<n><n>### Response <n>In order to find the density of a substance, you must multiply it's volume by the mass of a unit of the substance. So because we know that the measurement is per cubic foot, and the substance is labeled as a volume, the density factor would have to be to a mass in a cubic inch. Therefore the density factor is 55 pounds per foot(pounds/inch^3 =pounds/inches^3)/12(because there are 12 inches in a foot) 55 pounds per inch^3 and it's unit in pounds.<n><n><n>### Instructions:<n>Enter any letters from the list below.  Be careful, they may not always be the longest response.<n><n>### <n>B. The density of a substance is the measure of the amount of it in a given space.  Density(#/volume, units)<n>### <n>C. density is the amount of matter in a substance<n>### <n>D. density has a symbol of "ρ "and is measured in pounds per cubic foot as a unit<n>###<n>

Answer and how to calculate it.<n><n>### Input<n><n>Input:The turkey needed be kept from spoiling. What is useful in this situation. Choices A,B,C,D,E<n><n>### Response<n><n>A. The refrigerator<n><n>B. Frige<n><n>### Input :The rental agency charges $35 per day. How many days does it take to charge $166.75.<n>### Response<n>  **Answer**<n><n>C.<n><n>### Refrigerator : The refrigerator is cooler than the other. It has the right temperature to keep the turkey from spoiling. The freeze has the right room to keep the turkey, but it may not be used on the right place to keep food. The fridge is use to put food. The freeze is used to put food on. The oven is used to put food in. What is useful in the situation?<n><n>### Anwer<n><n>The refrigerator<n>### Input <n>Input:The rental agency charge $35 peach day. How many days it take to charge 166.74.<n><n>### Response <n>31<n><n>### Reason<n><n>The refridgerator is the only box that holds the turkey at the right temperature.<n><n>The other things in the box keep the right temperature.<n>The box is made of sturdy plastic. It will not break into tiny pieces.<n><n>### Anwar<n><n>The rental agency charged $35 a day and 31 days.<n><n>### Input  :Ms.Wheeler is the president of wheeler Company. Separate answers with a semicolon: ;*.<n><n>### Instrumental Variables:<n><n>In his report on the economy, David writes, "From 2010 to 2013, median income rose 21%. In 2014, it fell 3%, even though it rose again from 2015 to 2017.<n>"What was happening?"<n><n>1. Median income rose 236% in the mid 1970s. It rose 55% in the late 1980s, and 70% from 2010-12.<n>1. From 2015-17, median income dropped 3.3%, or 3.1% (round to lowest unit).<n>3. During the same time period, real GDP grew 4% in 2015, 7% in 2020, 8.8% in 2006, the 8.1% in 206, and 5.7% in 29.7%. The unemployment rate in 210/2/ was 4.7%, and it was 4.3% in 1985.<n><n>Answer Choices<n>1. The rise in median income is related to the rise in real GDP. <n>2. Median income went up during the recession (11/2/11-6/3/), then fell again before rising to the original levels.<n><n>---<n># Demonstrations<n><n>### Instructables<n><n><n>

The function also accepts a variable 'bodySize'  that describes what the tail is composed of. The function body should return an integer, of the length of the snake, excluding the tail, or the number of feet in the snake.<n><n>My Solution:<n><n>def snake_tail(bodysize):<n>    snake_body = bodysize # snake body length is equal to the value of 'bodysize'<n>    tail_length = 3 # the length of the snaketail is fixed to 3<n>    return (snake_body + tail_length) # return number of feet in the body, including the tail<n>
